contradictions.reality: Subject Access Request submitted 19 August 2025 includes documented health breaches, logging without consent, unlawful disclosure to NHS, and withheld trustee records. Fringe is expected to omit named actors like Alice Wright and decision trails that justify removal.

laws.why: Breach of lawfulness, fairness, and transparency
Failure to provide data upon request
Subject Access Request statute
Criminal offence to destroy/alter post-SAR

contradictions.title: Libel Broadcast and 'Finding Someone New' — Replacement Intent
contradictions.claim: Brighton Fringe sent a neutral update to stakeholders regarding venue operations.
contradictions.reality: On 18 July 2025, Brighton Fringe sent a mass email libelling Ben Carter as “abusive,” “unfit,” and “not a safe person to work with,” while simultaneously signalling a replacement. This email was sent to over 160+ artists, misrepresented safeguarding disclosures, and omitted legal context.

laws.why: Mass publication of libel
Misuse of board authority

reputational: Severe damage to professional standing across client base
emotional: Distress following public invalidation of safeguarding claims
financial: Loss of future bookings and venue collapse

contradictions.title: Safeharming — Logging the Risk, Choosing Inaction
contradictions.claim: Brighton Fringe could not have known Ben Carter was at risk.
contradictions.reality: Duncan Lustig-Prean and Amy Keogh confirmed they had been logging all messages, including those disclosing mental health crisis and suicidal thoughts. Yet no action was taken. This turns silence into intent.

laws.why: Safeguarding risk not acted upon
Failure to uphold right to life

medical: Exacerbated suicide risk due to inaction
emotional: Feelings of abandonment and betrayal by institution

contradictions.title: No Record of Allegations — Governance Gaslighting
contradictions.claim: Brighton Fringe had no record of safeguarding allegations.
contradictions.reality: After receiving forwarded emails, police screenshots, and disclosures, Brighton Fringe still claimed to have 'no record of allegations' from the victim. This appears to be a deflection strategy and contradiction of internal knowledge.

laws.why: Failure to accurately process safeguarding data
Omission of risk disclosures

legal: Potential breach of data transparency obligations

contradictions.title: Suicide Disclosure Met With Threat Instead of Safeguarding
contradictions.claim: Brighton Fringe provided trauma-informed safeguarding support.
contradictions.reality: After disclosing a suicide attempt in a meeting on April 9, 2025, Ben Carter was met not with a safeguarding plan, but with a threat: publication of communications would lead to withdrawal of support. This response directly contradicts their safeguarding escalation policy and legal duties.

laws.why: No safeguarding action initiated
Trustee failure to report serious incident
No formal logging or processing of risk disclosure
Right to life — failure to act on known risk

contradictions.title: Brighton Fringe Used Expired Contract to Justify Removal and Silenced Disclosures
contradictions.claim: Brighton Fringe operated fairly, transparently, and according to a valid agreement.
contradictions.reality: All punitive actions taken against Ben Carter in 2025 were based on an expired 2024 agreement. Brighton Fringe never issued a 2025 Venue Managers’ Agreement, despite changing their operational model. They ignored communication duties, failed to respond to safeguarding disclosures, and offered no transparency about the decision to remove him.

laws.why: Ben Carter never agreed to 2025 terms
Lack of transparent trustee decision making
Ignored safeguarding disclosures

contradictions.title: Fringe Co-Branded Early Marketing Then Erased Its Partner
contradictions.claim: Brighton Fringe operated in partnership with venues and upheld shared promotional responsibilities.
contradictions.reality: Ben Carter paid for and designed a co-branded station-wide poster campaign at Brighton Station, advertising 157 shows across 6 venues. Brighton Fringe later removed his venue and erased all acknowledgement of this partnership.

laws.why: Failure of trustee oversight and honesty
Breach of duty to act fairly and in good faith

contradictions.title: Fringe Admitted Its System Was Unmanageable and Still Shifted Blame
contradictions.claim: Brighton Fringe maintained operational control and supported partner venues.
contradictions.reality: On April 23, 2025, the Fringe's Box Office Manager admitted in writing that the new system could not track unticketed capacity. This directly led to insurance failures, public confusion, and unresolvable risk management issues.

laws.why: Service delivered without reasonable care
Director-level negligence

contradictions.title: Fringe Blamed Partner for Brochure They Made Unprintable
contradictions.claim: Ben Carter failed to produce materials for Brighton Fringe and was unfit for the festival.
contradictions.reality: The Fringe accused Ben of failing to produce a brochure in the 18 July 2025 libel email. But evidence shows it was fully designed and ready to print. Their own failures made it legally unprintable: including their logo posed risk, and removing it would be framed as hostile.

laws.why: Libel through misrepresentation
Reputational misuse

contradictions.title: Eventotron Payment Made in Good Faith Based on Manipulated Partnership Promise
contradictions.claim: Half a Camel operated as an independent and non-compliant platform, separate from Brighton Fringe.
contradictions.reality: Ben Carter paid Eventotron £250 to implement a mirror ticketing system under guidance from Brighton Fringe. This was a stall tactic used to delay brochure printing and ensure he couldn't act independently before being erased.

laws.why: False representation of partnership
Failure to act with care and honesty

contradictions.title: Shows and Venues Still Registering While Carter Was Being Covertly Stalled
contradictions.claim: Operational failure necessitated immediate removal of Half a Camel.
contradictions.reality: New venues and shows (Maris & Otter, Alec Crane) were still registering under Half a Camel through May 6. While operations were growing, Fringe staff were deflecting and isolating the infrastructure to create future reputational collapse.

laws.why: Misuse of payment under misleading framing

contradictions.title: Fringe Accused Carter of Not Delivering Brochure They Strategically Delayed
contradictions.claim: Ben Carter failed to deliver basic marketing assets such as the festival brochure.
contradictions.reality: The 2025 brochure was fully designed and ready to print. Brighton Fringe’s delayed approvals and contradictory guidance made printing legally uncertain. The absence was then used in a defamatory July 18 email.

laws.why: Libel through misrepresentation
Breach of trust and institutional honesty

contradictions.title: Brighton Fringe Used My Personal Phone for Box Office, Then Blamed Me for Collapse
contradictions.claim: Brighton Fringe intervened to protect the public and their reputation because I was no longer operational.
contradictions.reality: A member of the public called me, believing my number was the official Brighton Fringe support line. This proves the Brighton Fringe ticketing and performer tracking system had failed. I was fielding customer service calls, describing visible collapse, trying to salvage their reputation, and contemplating going rogue to ensure the shows could go ahead — while being blamed and erased.

laws.act: Consumer Protection from Unfair Trading Regulations 2008
laws.why: The public had no access to performer or event contact details.
Failure to act transparently and protect public safety.

contradictions.title: Artists Assumed I Was the Fringe Due to Their Absence
contradictions.claim: Ben Carter acted outside of his venue manager role and undermined Brighton Fringe coordination.
contradictions.reality: On March 29, 2025, an act emailed Brighton Fringe confused about flyering licences and assumed Ben Carter was responsible for handling them. This exchange proves the Fringe had failed to lead basic logistics, and that Carter had become the default point of coordination in the minds of artists and partners.

laws.why: Trustees failed to ensure delivery of basic responsibilities

laws.act: Consumer Protection from Unfair Trading Regulations 2008
laws.why: Fringe withheld operational support without notice

contradictions.title: Brighton Fringe Co-Branded Poster Misled Public While Knowing Venues Were Unsafe
contradictions.claim: Brighton Fringe acted to protect audiences and their brand integrity through careful curation and risk management.
contradictions.reality: Brighton Fringe approved and co-branded a Brighton Station poster campaign with Ben Carter’s Half a Camel Productions. The poster featured both logos and directed the public to the Fringe’s ticketing system, implying institutional safety and unity. At the time, the Fringe knew the advertised venues were uninsurable. The logo placement reassured the public while hiding operational collapse — and Carter was erased shortly after.

laws.why: False representation through co-branding
Breach of trustee duties through misrepresentation
Failure to exercise reasonable care in marketing
Misleading advertising to the public
